title: The Hunger to Return
summary: After a full immersion in the Diamond Luminosity, life reorganizes around a single gravitational center: the yearning to go back. Past joys become thin echoes; the ecstatic language of the Sufi poets feels literal, not metaphor. The author recognizes himself as the lover condemned to seek the Beloved, his attention magnetized by the memory of becoming Light beyond time and space. Stormy Mountain stages the necessary counter-movement to such rapture. Instead of ascent, there is drift: half-formed cleansings that do not culminate, flashes of union that refuse to hold. Frustration exposes a subtle demand—that grace repeat on cue. In an effort to reopen the gate, he calls on the music that had previously borne him into luminous death. But the rite fails; the body convulses and empties. The instrument that once dissolved the world now dramatizes the disparity between memory and presence. The attempt to re-create the peak reveals an ethical law of the path: you cannot coerce the Beloved. From this defeat a new devotion is born. Night, rain, and a mountainside gather into an imaginal rite of fidelity. The same music becomes not the voice of God singing him home, but his own voice singing from outside the gates. He knows the Beloved is his Essential Nature, known before and knowable again. Exile is not separation but apprenticeship. Song turns longing into form, a vow sounded across the storm: we have embraced; we will embrace again. In singing, pain softens and becomes a compass rather than a wound. The session reconstitutes desire as covenant—less a craving for state, more a trust in the continuity of relationship through absence. The path matures from acquisition of experiences to an orientation of heart. The gate remains closed, yet the bond is clarified; the hunger distills into a steady promise to return. In that promise, time itself is redeemed: the interruption is brief, the arc intact, the love unwavering.
notes: This section reframes peak-state nostalgia as a discipline of fidelity, warning against ritualized coercion while inaugurating a mature vow—advancing the book’s arc from ecstatic attainment to enduring relational wisdom.
